cons: Due to budget cuts since Covid, there are fewer resources than in the past and some faculty and staff are feeling stretched. However, we're gradually returning to "normal."

job_title: Major Gifts Officer in Boston, MA
pros: Great 403b match program up to 9%

pros: honestly right now only the people I have been working for years with do I enjoy about Suffolk. Marisa as acting President has done a lot for the University over the past few years. Along with a new Board has help with moving forward.
cons: After years of no raises the university has been giving some raises but it doesn't matter how much work you do; whether you put in several extra hours while the person next to you doing the same job barely shows up on time and leaves early if the boss isn’t in. Oh and can't stay off of his Facebook or other sites not work related at all for a majority of the day yet he gets the same increase in salary.  Motivation to work hard and help the University achieve its goals has diminished greatly and I am at the point of exiting. It’s a shame since I had enjoy working here for years prior.

review_title: If you find the right niche and meet the right people, it is the best place to learn and grow as a person.
job_title: IT Lab Assistant At CAS in Boston, MA
pros: Lots of job and internship opportunities, resources to help fuel your passions, dedicated faculty in all departments if you seek them out and show you care, good financial aid if you need it, good work study program
cons: The administration mucks up the works for students and faculty. So many people get frustrated because they will have a good idea that gets stonewalled by red tape from administration that feels it needs to go through endless amounts of other people in other departments to get any one thing done. There are simple things that become complicated.

pros: Location in downtown Boston is fun.
cons:
There is extremely poor leadership at Suffolk University, starting with the President(s) and trickling down through the Deans and Directors. Entry level staff are excluded from professional development opportunities, meetings and retreats and conferences - yet are asked to do the leg work to make those things happen for other people. They elevate inexperienced Suffolk Alumni into positions of management that they are unfit for and do not seek the opinions of those being ineffectually managed. I was told by a colleague within my first week at Suffolk that I should not expect to ever be promoted because Suffolk "just doesn't work that way." In my brief time with the school (I quit for these very reasons...) I watched several people in the Division quit and many more consider leaving.

I would highly suggest every candidate consider long and hard whether or not they are interested in working for a University that has notoriously low employee satisfaction, low salaries compared to the other Boston schools, and famed disorganization and strife at the top levels of leadership. I would NEVER allow anyone I cared about to work at Suffolk University.

review_title: Excellent, dedicated mid and entry level staff, poor upper management
pros: I worked with many dedicated, student centered professionals who gave a lot of time and energy to the university under very unfavorable circumstances.  President McKenna has managed to unite much of the community behind her, but she is due to leave in a year, and there are no dynamic leaders among the current admin.
cons: The upper administration has either all left or is too distracted by the media circus and constant staffing challenges to do what is right for the students.  Everyone is swimming upstream here.  Long hours, no raises in 6 years, micro-management from provosts and deans to create an image. Programs and initiatives that never quite get implemented. Construction projects unfinished due to financial concerns. It has been a rough 6 years for Suffolk.

review_title: Former employee. Looking for a rewarding career in higher ed? Look elsewhere.
pros: Decent work life balance, reasonable benefits, great location.
cons:
Little room for growth, horrific management. Very little in the way of compensation adjustments for cost of living in the 6 years I worked there.  My job responsibilities ended up being much more than my original description and yet the pay was still laughably bad. 

Management had no idea nor cared about the impact of years of progressive improvements I was responsible for.  Your supervisor will only listen to people that strokes their ego and if you go above him to address concerns, no one will care. 

Very low morale throughout, leading to a toxic workplace due to the fact of everyone on edge about their continued employment.

pros: As a student employee it is nice to work on campus, and you are able to schedule around your classes. You connect with other students and form a good relationship with the university staff in your department.
cons: When someone leaves a position at suffolk it takes more than a semester for someone new to be hired for the open position. This means more work and stress for you and everyone else around you. Due to budget cuts all privet budgets for paying student employees has been seriously cut down. Myself and others were given serious payouts that made living in Boston without another job, impossible. Make sure you are being given a chance to work your full work study reward because they are not looking out to make sure you get to work your entire allotment.

review_title: Not so bad as far as jobs go but could be better
pros: Free undergrad classes if you are an employee. Lots of appreciation days and inner office celebrations (weddings/baby showers, etc.) HR very good at explaining benefits and helping in that area.I found forums and lectures enlightening when I was able to attend. Decent pay.
cons:
Red tape. Everything needs to go down a chain of command and a lot of time is wasted. Unfortunately by the time something gets approved it is a rush job. This creates unnecessary work stress. HR is there for upper management and not very helpful if support staff has issues 
(contrary to what orientation booklets and videos would have you think).

review_title: So much potential, yet so much dysfunction
pros: The stated values are awesome, and there are some really special students here.
cons: The organization, at all levels, is dysfunctional. There is little guiding strategy or accountability. Too much reliance on spending money and making things over reflection, planning, accountability, and results.

review_title: I work in central administration for the University.
pros: The students are terrific--hard-working, friendly, engaging.  The staff, particularly in student life, are deeply committed to the students' personal growth and professional success. The benefits and time off are excellent.
cons: The senior leadership is unstable and is not currently demonstrating a true understanding of who our students are nor enough respect for the knowledge and value of the central administration. There is not a strong management system nor support for professional development. The culture and environment used to be positive but with the arrival of the interim president, morale among the mid-level administration is poor.

review_title: No opportunities for advancement for hardworkers, backstabbing is the norm, great place for good BSers.
pros: If you like politics, are good at talking the talk during meetings, have grown up with the university, gone to school at Suffolk then you will do well.
cons: If you try to make positive changes you won't do well.  If you work hard for the university you won't do well.  If you are nice you won't do well.  Change is not acceptable.  Working well with coworkers is seen as a threat to supervisors.  Watch your back, rub elbows with the right people, and be tough then you might do well.  The culture has changed, management is top heavy and you have to be there for 20+ years to survive.  If you are nice forget it, you won't survive.

pros: Good benefits, tuition is free. Relaxed work environment with many avenues for advancement.  I worked in all parts of the university over a 10 year period. The college of liberal arts is the most laid back, the school of management was ok and the law school was the most professional.
cons: In the school of management they stopped using asst. profs. that worked in a given field and replaced the with Ph.D. to get a certain accreditation. This caused a change from profs that really knew what they were talking about and profs that were more interested in getting published than in teaching.

review_title: It is a nice place to work.
pros: Many of the faculty members are bright people willing to help with advice and who care about their students. I can say the same about the staff members - many of them are truly into their work and want their students to succeed. Great location, benefits, and PTO.
cons: The university is torn between emphasis on its teaching function and the desire to achieve more recognition for research. Excellence in both is what the university requires, but since both require considerable time and effort, achieving excellence in one of the areas is often at the expense of the other.

job_title: Data Entry Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Supervisor was a kind lady who likes to hang out with interns, have professional conversations, eat lunch together and share stories. The management in the admissions department is led by very nice people. Great learning experience and laid back work during the summer.
cons: Not everyone gets equal opportunity here. The system is a little biased; rather bullies. Employees in this department are very fake, smiley face on the outside, scheme-full on the inside. You can never really tell what these people are thinking. These all happen behind managements back, they have no clue who they're hiring.

review_title: Can't put my support behind this university any longer.
pros: Amazing feedback from direct supervisors, positive departmental working environments, wonderful coworkers, free tuition, time off benefits, healthcare benefits, work/life balance.
cons: No raises in six years, constantly being asked to undertake more work with absolutely no compensation (and no hope of future compensation) while administration at the top continues to get raises and hire new, "specialized" staff, while support staff are told they cannot have raises because there is no money, no room for advancement, university hamstrings faculty (who also have not had raises in many years) by telling them to dedicate themselves further to a university that does not respect them, students falling through the cracks, admittance of students who require additional, specialized services that are not available at this university

pros: They are friendly and understanding of the position and the fact that every RA is a full time student as well. It is great to feel so connected to a great community
cons: Very busy and there is not a lot of support for the RAs that are working hard for them. There are many inefficient processes in place that hamper work

review_title: Glad to be spending my time here
pros: Because I am a student, it is convenient to work at an office within the school so that the schedules coincide (meaning I won't have issues with a summer internship, etc.). It's also a great way to learn about all of the opportunities available to me while I am a student here.
cons: The office I work in as a graduate fellow is not really related to what I am getting my master's in.

review_title: Don't let the brand fool you.
pros:
• Free tuition
• Vacation Time
• Great staff, everyone just saying genuinely great, respectively. There are a few bad apples but what company doesn't have them.
cons:
• Currently in a pay freeze that doesn't seem to be changing in the near future. 
• Payroll system is paper based, time sheets are literally, sheets that require filling at the top of the week
• Within this department, growth is very limited. Try your luck in other departments.

pros: People at Suffolk University are so cooperative and accepting. Everyone likes to work as a team looking forward to what is best which leads to an easy-going working atmosphere.
cons: While I'm working at Suffolk University, I am pursuing my bachelor degree on the other side. Therefore, working sometimes interrupts my studying schedule.

pros: Flexible work schedule, low stress, tuition benefits
cons: The institution itself is extremely political run by people with huge egos. There is lack of leadership and strategy for running a better school. Many employees gossip and complain about higher level positions behind their back. Appears that the administration is very disconnected with the true student experience. Low pay and complacency. There is no motivation for people to do better or improve things.

review_title: board of trustees still needs an overhaul
pros: great faculty, great location, reasonably priced education, graduate programs (business and law) are good
cons: lack of strategic thinking on board of trustees; top-down management style; resource constraints; administration largely ad hoc (not professional or consistent); short-term mentality, very low transparency/accountability, little support for faculty research, poor student services; little quality control; no raises for faculty/staff; illusion of shared governance

job_title: Anonymous Employee in East Boston, MA
pros: University has superb benefits compared to corporate jobs and other universities. Health insurance is possibly one of the best you will find, and can't beat the paid time off. Tuition get's covered for the family. I work with a great team, and have a great manager which makes coming to work a pleasure.
cons: Currently a culture of layoffs, no promotion from within or room for growth, no salary raises for 5+ years.

pros: working with students; relaxed work culture; good coworkers
cons: you cannot work with HR at all, they're insulting and degrading; forget a raise/promotion/recognition/explanation of anything, you'll always get the standard HR "I'm sorry you experienced this" response; honestly, HR and their inability to do their job is the sole reason I hate coming to work everyday; no trust/no respect and totally disconnected from the university's community

pros: The office culture is great. It is laid back and there is a lot of flexibility with regards to work. People are collaborative and friendly with regards to programming. There is a lot of room for professional development as well.
cons: Recent changes in administration and policies make it hard for lower level positions to efficiently do their jobs.

review_title: Good benefits, unthoughtful Leadership team and HR department.
pros: Suffolk has great benefits and I really enjoyed working with my immediate team.
cons: The leadership (VPs, President's Office, Provost, etc) make unthoughtful, uninformed decisions without thought for the school based teams implementing the changes. Many are not qualified for their positions and have not work elsewhere (therefore lacking an outside perspective or practical experience)

pros: Location in the City is perfect near boston common and T-stops
cons:
Professionalism is non-existant
Most employees do about 50% of the responsibilities and then tries to con the other 50% on others of=r just forget about it
Board of Trustees are useless, can't figure out a president
HR has had 4 different benefit coordinators in 1 year
IT is slow and then complains

pros: The institution has a strong mission and does great work in the community, and the students are hard working
cons: The leadership is dysfunctional, the board of trustees is unnecessarily meddlesome to the detriment of good work getting done, and it is a culturally toxic workplace

pros: Employee Benefits, especially 403B match and Tuition Remission
cons: Communication silos, immature or poorly implemented systems, uncooperative colleagues, no organizational knowledge transfer / documentation for most areas

review_title: Gives Student Perspective from Professor Standpoint
pros: It is an opportunity for students to work for the school who can't get a work study. You get to teach a freshman class with a professor. It is a fun experience seeing how professor plan ahead of time and the challenges you face while trying to teach students and keeping them entertained.
cons: The professor you are working with may have different planning structures than you do.

review_title: Toxic Culture, Poor Management, University Failing
pros:
1. Work with great people (staff, students, faculty, even the security guards!)
2. Good time off benefits
3. 401k Matching is a robust percentage. 
4. Option for flexible, 4-day week in the summer ("Summer Fridays")
cons:
1. Completely dysfunctional management implements changes without any foresight or thought of the long-term effects on staff, students, or how departments are run. When asked to elaborate, they don't have and/or won't give answers.
2. Some staff (not faculty) manage to take 10 weeks off ANNUALLY. There is zero accountability in some departments. 
3. No raises in SIX, yes, SIX years. Cost of living goes up, Suffolk salaries, except for upper administration, stagnate. 
4. Tuition-based funding of the university, lacks a robust endowment so financial decisions (hiring, firing, and raises for upper administration) depends on enrollment of full-pay students.
5. No internal hires, no promotions. What you're hired for is your job: forever unless you get a degree here or manage to get in an office with administrators.
6. HR just introduced their version of "Pay Day Loans" because compensation is moving to a bi-weekly system. Compensation is already so low that people need a loan to keep body and soul together. 
7. Administration is dismissive of support staff all the way up to the President. 
8. Annual mass firings, staff fired without explanation, culture of fear that means people are afraid to advocate for themselves or their departments.

Run, do not walk, away from this place. From what I understand, this place was once a great local school where you could get a decent degree, get your credential, and move along. I guarantee that it will not be here in 10 years. Low staff morale, limited alumni support, dysfunctional management and Board of Trustees, this place is in the local papers every other week and not for its accomplishments as a university.

pros: Interaction with the students. Flexible hours. Able to do individual research. Stimulating environment. Friendly staff. Help students with their experiments.
cons: Bad management that lacks vision. No annual wage reviews. It is difficult if not impossible to communicate with management. Money is not handled well by management.

review_title: The current leadership is frustrating and unfocused.
pros: Great support staff. Very helpful IT staff.  Friendly, dedicated student body who are serious about their education and pro-bono experiences.
cons: Lack of administrative support. No cost of living raises. No performance based raises. Frustrating bureaucracy and leadership decisions.  Many buildings need lots of updates.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Boston, MA
pros: Suffolk University is a diverse and cultural organization and respectful of each individual not only in terms of ethnicities but also of one's knowledge and perspective
cons: However they do not value you in monetary terms

review_title: Staff Assistant Review of Suffolk University
pros: Centrally located in downtown Boston.
cons: Very mismanaged organization, poor job advancement/ growth opportunities, no pay increases in five years.  Anyone who's not in upper management is not adequately compensated and workers usually handle the duties of several workers.

pros: The staff and students are great. Good benefits. Great location - easy to get to. Occasionally, they have some nice events for the staff.
cons: Not well organized. Staff who do a good job are not recognized accordingly. Not much room for advancement. Lots of cuts meaning more work for those at the hourly level without any compensation. Poor leadership at all levels, especially the law school.

review_title: No raises, no recognition, no one cares.
pros: Decent benefits for retirement and health. Good CIO. Great faculty.
cons: No raises in 5 years yet upper administration is paid handsomely and wastes money on anything they dream up. Difficult to get necessary things done.

pros: Benefit package is worth taking advantage of
cons: Your take home pay is an embarrassment to the University, your family, and the USA

review_title: Treats its own horribly with advancement
pros: They hired a president, finally
cons: political upheaval, no leadership, employee morale low, does not take care of its own and its alumni.

review_title: It was a great experience to work at here.
pros:
The flexibility of the job is a great plus. It will allow you to do your work more efficiently.
A great supervisor will grow you up.
cons: I cannot think of any problems about this job.

job_title: Agile Project Manager in Boston, MA
pros: Good quality education and great professors
cons: Boston being a city with high cost of living doesnt help much with this low salary. They dont provide any job during summer. International students face a lot of struggle to study at Suffolk with such high cost of living and high tuition

pros: Flexible hours (4 day work week for some), availability to work remotely, some nice people.  free tuition if you have the time and patience!
cons: I worked there for 4 years with no raise, promotion, or interaction with HR. Strangely secluded in an academic hall basement.

pros: Great location. Meaningful mission and history. Some great colleagues. Students who matter and need education as a bridge to a brighter future.
cons: Corrupt administration. The word honesty should be removed from the seal and replaced with deception. I’ve worked at three universities. This is truly a special case of corruption.

pros: Amount of vacation time, students, expanding student body - not just for locals anymore
cons: management is not supportive, not sure what it wants to be, too corporate, the pay is very low compared to other private universities in the area.
